ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Arctic Glacier USA is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  Arctic Glacier USA has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Arctic Glacier USA is located at 2003 S. Cherry Avenue in Fresno, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility's refrigeration system to provide cooling for production and storage of ice.  The system uses a maximum of 14,000 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below:



The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver to the Subcooler and Direct Expansion Evaporators (Room 6 & 7). Subcooled liquid is sent to the Low Temp Pump Receivers (2), Ice Bin Surge Drum & Evaporator, Room 2 Surge Drums and Evaporators, and Tigar Turbo Ice Maker and Surge Drum. The two Pump Receivers send recirculated liquid to the Turbo Ice Makers and Freezer Evaporators (Room 3, 4, & 5). The vapor from each piece of equipment is returned through the main suction header to the Accumulators (2).  Each accumulator has an associated Transfer Vessel which sends liquid to a third Transfer Vessel which returns liquid ammonia to the High Pressure Receiver.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



A review of the facility's five year accident history showed that there have been no incidents at the facility that meet the RMP criteria for a reportable accident (onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place).  In addition, there have been no incidents at the facility in the last five years that resulted in a release of more than the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds). 



The facility did have one release in October 2017 in which the oil return line from the coalescer on the oil side of Compressor #5 released oil and ammonia vapor into the engine room. The refrigeration contractor was onsite and activated the E Stop and closed the King valve to stop the release. As a precautionary measure the building was evacuated and notifications were made to the NRC, state and CUPA. It was determined that metal fatigue and harmonic vibration caused the stainless steel tubing compression fitting to break. Repairs were made to the line. Less than 25 lbs of ammonia mixed with oil were released.



They also had one near miss that involved a forklift impacting a small pipe on LTA-1 in the engine room however no ammonia was released from the system. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Arctic Glacier USA has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of

an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the fire department for assistance as necessary.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Process Hazard Analysis and Compliance Audits have been performed on the ammonia refrigeration system, and these studies have resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Arctic Glacier USA has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.
